data.text: It has little to do with the gender of the author, protagonist, etc. Olga Tokarczuk is just as appealing to male readers as David Foster Wallace (who is considered 'bro lit'). It seems to be more directly related, interestingly enough, to the postmodernist divide in literature.

(Gonna out myself as an insufferable millennial bro and say David Foster Wallace—his maximalism expands my sense of what's possible on the page, as does his notorious blend of academic and colloquial prose. I swear the copy of INFINITE JEST on my shelf is not a display piece.)

tweets.text: Now, the majority of readers are women, but I'm curious, not about why fewer men read, but why those who do veer toward literary fiction. Bigger, more complicated books about complex ideas. This appeals to male readers at a higher rate than female readers. Why?
